answers.author: Julie Steenson
answers.text:
Perhaps another way to look at turnover would be to restrict it to "% new hires retained after (x) months/year(s) of employment".    This might be more interesting than the larger turnover rate, particularly if you are trying to infuse the organization with a new culture.    Do you perform exit interviews with standard "reasons for leave"?  If so, that might be good data to look at.  
My community is currently coordinating with staff to create an employee survey as well.  Our focus in that effort is of course to gather some end user data to set baselines for our satisfaction outcome measures.   However, many of our current measures are output or cycle time focused.  In our performance management efforts,  we are examining the balance between thoroughness and speed of our hiring and application process.  We measure several timeframes related to that process and are seeking technology solutions to help with user satisfaction and timeliness.  
Dr. David Ammons book on Municipal Benchmarks has a few suggestions that might be useful for you also.  And I couldn't post on an ICMA site without of course recommending taking a look at the CPM templates.

answers.author: Matthew Reges
answers.text:
That's interesting. It's true that turnover will go along with reform, as structures, expectations, and cultures change. Indeed, if there was no turnover, you might wonder if the reforms were really having an effect.
Your survey items of satisfaction, engagement, and morale will help, though the survey needs to be anonymous and trusted to protect employees: for that reason our HR office contracts our employee survey administration to the state university and only sees their final report. 
Our city is not doing transformational reform, and our measures of motivation and engagement are survey responses and a simple turnover statistic.
Brainstorming other indicators of satisfaction and engagement:
*Use of sick leave/absenteeism & tardiness. Has the rate changed?
*Volume or rate of internal applicants for promotional jobs. Do employees want to stay and move up? An easy statistic for your civil service office to report.
*Exit interviews. For what turnover there is, unpack the good from the bad and what motivates it.  Getting full disclosure can be tricky, and some cities use contracted professionals, job coaches or counselors, to do exit interviews. 
*Traditions as meaningful indicators. If there are parades, parties, or rituals that bring employees together, is attendance and energy up? Or conversely, if the garage vending machine is where griping traditionally happens, and the machine is not selling out the way it used to, maybe less griping is occurring? There may be offbeat data like this which correlate with morale --granted the behavior may change (Hawthorne) if measurement is known.
What do you think?

answers.author: Tom Nosack
answers.text:
What you are asking for is possible, but there are a few caveats:
a. You are looking for trends of at least three years. Year to year variance will often be outside factors
b. Display public safety separate from the rest of the municipality – public safety has a separate rate influenced by other factors.
c. Gather data from as many of these factors as possible; the combination will tell the story.
Useful statistics to “draw the picture” without a survey:
A. Employee turnover by year
B. Average years of service per employee – newer employees will start to leave first, then retirements will pick up
C. Sick time and FMLA time used per employee (Used more if stress requires it or if planning to leave)
D. Number of formal HR complaints filed, number sustained
E. Vacation time used (People stop using it if contemplating departure)
F. Participation in municipal activities (picnics, blogs, etc) They will decrease as employees pull back, increase as they feel greater affinity for the organization
There are more, but this will give you a good feel for the situation.
G. If you decide to survey and want to help with transformational change, the University of Texas (Austin) does a low cost, highly effective “survey of organizational excellence” process they have been doing for over a decade. Highly recommended, just Google it. If things are at rock bottom, it is an excellent time to establish a baseline!

author: Oliver Wise
text:
I am the performance management director for a municipality that is historically dysfunctional and is undergoing significant transformational reforms. We are identifying citywide outcome measures, and for our city workforce services area, we are discussing which would be a good measure to select. We know that an employee survey, similar to the one Gallup uses, is probably the best way to obtain good information about the job satisfaction and engagement of the city work force? But are there other good, non-survey derived measures? Employee turnover is one suggested measure, but some have argued that in an organization undergoing reforms, high turnover is to be expected and may not necessarily be undesirable?
What measures do you use in your organizations?
title: Is turnover a good outcome measure for human resources services?
